segments.text: But the press relations with the Union?
What's that?
Who were some of the press and journalists who sided with the seamen or helped them propaganda-wise?
How was Heywood Broon?
Oh, Heywood Broon was very good.
He was very good in labor generally.
I just for the moment can't remember what he wrote about the NMU, about the seamen.
I remember once he gave quite a boost to the Daily Worker.
He recommended that everyone who wanted to keep informed should read the New York Times and the Daily Worker, those two papers.
And he was writing for another paper.
That's quite interesting.
In the 1920s, how many people were you familiar with?
who were in the generation of the 1920s besides that hung around with the John Reed crowd.
How's that?
Who were some other personalities whom you were familiar with when you were a journalist in the 20s and in the 30s?
Ezra Pound or Faulkner or Hemingway or any of these personalities?
I didn't know Hemingway.
One of my very good friends on the paper who died, Joe North, knew Hemingway very well from Spain.
I was in Spain too, but after Hemingway was out.
Well, when did you go to Spain?
I was the last American reporter of any kind in Madrid.
I got there at the
The very end of, let's see, the end of, probably the last day of February, or the first of March, 1939, when the war was lost.
But I'd been fighting to get over there for some time.
And finally the decision was, in the paper, well,
even though whether there's any chance of winning the war or not, we should be there.
Because on the surface, the war seemed lost, but if it could hang on, the international situation might possibly change, you see.
Anyhow, Hemingway was already out, and
I got to Madrid.
First, it was very difficult to get into Spain.
Air France used to have a plane flying from Toulouse to Barcelona, then to Valencia.
then to Alicante, and then to Oran in Algeria.
But it had cut out the three Spanish stations.
It said it would fly direct to Oran, and sometimes there'd be a flight from Oran then to Alicante and back.
Well, I took a chance.
It was a sheer gamble.
I flew from Toulouse to Oran.
There I, the representative of Air France there was a young Englishman.
He also represented Cook's Tours.
You know about that.
And he said to me, no chance of getting on the plane to Iran.
We're booked for the next two flights.
There are two flights a week.
And no chance.
Well, I sized him up.
I talked to him a little.
I found he was a rather lonely, disgruntled young man.
He was unhappy on his job.
I told him that I was a little lonely, and I would like to have a drink with him.
It lasted for hours.
And in the morning, he told me at the end, be sure to be at the office at 8 o'clock in the morning.
And he pushed me in ahead of some people who were screaming, indignantly.
So I got to Alicante, and all that was left of the Popular Front then was the Communist Party.
The others had deserted.
The anarchists had went with the fifth column.

uh the uh the uh left the left socialists supported the government yes no i would say no the left socialists like the green uh and uh del vallo uh state pat i was incorrect to saying that the communists were the only one but they were the they were the only big organized force behind behind the the government well after three days in uh in alicante which is in southern
Spain, I got a ride, a hitchhike, to Valencia.
After four days in Valencia, I got another ride to Madrid.
When I got to Madrid at noon, I was told that the fifth column would strike any minute was there.
You may have heard of the fifth column.

There was a Spanish general named Mola, a fascist general, who once said earlier in the war, we have four columns marching on Madrid and we have a fifth column in Madrid which will strike when we come there.
Well, that fifth column that night rose at midnight.
The next morning, I went down to the
I was staying in a certain house.
I went down and there was only one, it was Monday, only one paper was published on Monday.
It was the anarchist paper.
It was filled with the fifth column manifestos.
And the anarchists were on that side.
Their theory was that
that we'll get rid of the communists, then we'll make a revolution.
Well, some of them believed that, but the leaders knew what they were doing.
Eventually, after the Fifth Column won, they turned things over to Franco without firing a shot.
Real treachery.
Well, anyhow, I went down to the Mundo Brera, which is the organ of the Communist Party,
And it was guarded by enemy troops.
But I decided to go inside anyhow, because I knew that the fighting would go on.
And I walked right into the trap quite consciously.
And so our building was under siege, machine guns rattling off the walls.
cutting into the sandbags at the windows, and our boys were shooting back.
So after some days there, we were...
In the first days, our side was winning.
The government forces had recaptured...

the the government buildings the ministry buildings franco franco made an attack but he was pushed back by an army made up dominated by communists and then then things changed an anarchist regiment came in from guadalajara and the the tide turned against
against the government forces.
So we had to evacuate Monroe Borough.
It was a big stone building, but we went then into the still stronger building, the party headquarters.
After two days there, that had to be given up.
I was with a group of five other people who were doing, four men and a woman, who had been doing radio work behind the fascist lines.
And we were arrested.
They almost shot us there as we got out in front of a great wall.
There were about 20 fifth columnists there, running around like crazy guys with Tommy guns.
It seemed a complete confusion, lack of organization.
One of them suddenly threw his gun down on us with a lot of curses, but the man beside him jerked it up.
Well, that was a tense moment, you can imagine.
And we were taken to the Seguridad police headquarters and held there.
first interrogated for some hours in an upper floor in the press office.
Then we were put in a cell for the condemned.
Well, I don't want to go into all that detail.
It was a pretty grim place there, a very tiny little place with a cement floor and a bloody floor where other prisoners had been, wounded men who had been taken out and shot.
There was a German, an Italian, a Hungarian, and a Frenchman.
And in a neighboring cell, we could see her sometimes at a window, was a Portuguese young woman who called herself Belgian for security reasons because they knew she was Portuguese.
She would just go out like that, you see.
because Portugal had a fascist regime.
So, well, this is outside of your story.
I don't know if you want any more of this.
This is fine.
So, the last day looked like our last day because we weren't fed.
The food, incidentally, was very simple.
Once a day,
A guard would throw in what they called a bacalao, which is half a codfish, raw, and salt.
You take two or three mouthfuls and your palate's burning.
No water with it.
And a small roll.
I broke a bridgework on the roll.
It was so stale.
Then we'd have to pound and scream for Agua, and we'd finally get her.
But there was one guard who was rather human.
At first, the worst guard would poke his head in and say, no Agua.
But you'd keep on pounding and yelling, and finally the guard who was somewhat human would take us one by one to the washroom to get Agua.
Well, finally, they had stolen my money, the guards.
I managed to hide some of my clothes.
But they hadn't, for some reason, taken my passport or my fountain pen or my notebook.
So I said to my friends, let's send telegrams, write telegrams to our ambassadors.
And mention the names of the most important people you can think of as though they were your friends.
They won't transmit the telegrams, but possibly this will deter them, you know, what they want to do, because it looked as though they were to be shot that day.
And it worked.
That is, we gave them to a guard, and I was taken up to the upper office, interrogated.
Now, my Spanish was very bad.
I decided not to use it at all.
I said I only knew American.
They tried to ask me where I was staying and where my baggage was.
They talked a little French and Spanish, imitated a man lifting baggage and so forth.
But I only knew American.
Then they brought in a cop who spoke in English, London English.
And I'd interviewed him when he was a prisoner of the government side.
He had been liberated by the victory of the fifth column.
Well, I had nothing left in my bag, but I just had to use what I had, which was nothing.
And I told him I only knew American, not London talk.
But it didn't work.
But they took me out.
Two cops.
Amateurs they were, cops.
And put their fingers to my throat, meaning it's the death sign.
I'd better tell them where I live.
So I took them to the embassy.
I knew where it was.
I hadn't been there.
When I got there, they were very angry.
They said, Abakadoa, very angry.
I said, no, no.
So I hollered at them to ring the bell.
There was a gate and...
a wall of masonry, an iron gate, and behind that, 25 or 30 feet away, was the big embassy building.
When I hollered him to push the button, he immediately, his finger automatically pressed it.
Well, the first man who came was a porter who, it turned out, was no good.
He was with the fascists.
But I wouldn't let them ask him to talk.
I'd holler louder than they did.
He went back for his chief, and the chief was a wonderful guy.
He was a Basque, knew English perfectly.
He was a custodian.
Roosevelt had taken all the diplomats out.
As he said himself after, Spain was my greatest mistake.
That's recorded by Ambassador Bowers in the book he wrote 14 years later.
Roosevelt told him that was his greatest mistake.
It was a terrible mistake because it helped to bring on the World War.
And you see, denying the right of closing America's ports to the shipment of munitions, which the Spaniards had the money to pay for.
So we got there, and finally the custodian came.
Fortunately, he was in.
If he hadn't been in, he said, you wouldn't be alive now.
And the argument went on for maybe 10 or 15 minutes, shouting on each side.
And he described me as a tremendously important journalist.
I certainly didn't, which was an exaggeration.
I didn't look the part.
I hadn't shaved for a long time, and clothes were dirty.
And finally I said, he was exhausted and he was drawing his, trying to recover his strength and I said, I'm very cold and sick.
I wasn't sick, but I was cold and I'm hungry.
I just want to get inside the wall out of the wind.
Well, another argument started and finally he talked them down and I was to go inside the wall.
Naturally, I didn't stay there.
I was set for the door as fast as I could.
He played football interference, tried to block them.
They knocked him aside.
But I had the door open.
It was a very heavy door, and I was going in when they grabbed me.
I pulled them in with me.
And so then they were scared.
What would happen to them?
One of them put his finger to his own throat if he didn't take me back.
He got regrets, but impossible.
And a little sort of an albister burlesque, a little interruption here.
As I got in, I was Joe Kennedy, John Kennedy's oldest brother, who died after he was in an airplane accident during the war.
he came to me and he asked me a stupid question.
What's the difference between the Bolsheviks and the Communists?
You know, as soon as I, when I was safe, suddenly I began to feel very all in.
And before that, you know, excitement and nerve kept you up, but I was in no mood to argue.
But, and he told me that, he explained the difference was that the Communists
favor a bloody revolution.
And the socialists don't.
This was in the embassy?
Well, I just said to him, their bodies were picked up in front of this embassy.
Who started the blood?
I said, in the fifth column, one of the leaders is a right-wing socialist.
It was true.
There was division in the Socialist Party.
But the communists didn't start it.
But anyhow, the custodian...
intervened and he said, please excuse Mr. Shields, my wife wants to give him some deed.
Afterwards he said to me, I don't know what this young man is doing here, he says he can write but he can't write.
I found out afterwards from my friends in touch with the embassy and he was attached to the embassy in France and that he was there to
negotiate with the fifth column on behalf of his father, who was then an ambassador in London, and working with Chamberlain with the appeasement crowd.
Roosevelt finally broke with him and had to drop him.
Well, that's sort of aside from the story, but what I did was immediately I persuaded the custodian to go to the Seguridad and
appealed for the safety of the men I left behind, and he did it.
He intervened very vigorously.
As he told me, he had no authority to do it.
After all, he was only a custodian, not a diplomat.
But it worked.
I was told afterwards by one of the men, a Balderian in Balderia, that they were taken before a machine gun for execution two hours after I left.
And then, before the shots were fired, a policeman ran up and said, the orders are changed.
Then they were transmitted to Valencia also.
I didn't see them there.
And they were almost shot when Franco came in, but somehow or other they were very clever, they took themselves out of it.
The Italian comrade was shot, he was taken back to Italy and executed, but the German
The German told the felonist, the stupid Spanish fascist representative, that he came from Lubbock, which he said is a free city, it's not part of the Reich.
Well, in the Middle Ages it was brought to the Hanseatic League of Mercantile Cities, you know.
But they didn't know any better.
And they didn't shoot him and kept him seven years.
He got tuberculosis, but finally he was sent home.
He became a well-known author on novels and decorated afterwards.
I met him four years ago.
I had a very nice meeting with him in Germany.
Well, that's sort of off the National Maritime Union.
Back to the union itself, back to the National Maritime Union, how long did you cover them for the daily worker, or the waterfront?
Well, I should say, through the 40s, I did other things too, but it was, it took a good, it was something I gave major attention to.
Then I was sent to Pittsburgh to a series of trials of communist leaders in Pittsburgh.
And two people got a total of 25 years, but in two different trials, both state and federal.
But all the cases were thrown out.
by the Supreme Court eventually.
But the trials dragged on.
One trial lasted nine months.
There are dramatic moments in trials, but most of it's very boresome, sitting there.
But someone had to do it.
It was a job that had to be done.
And I could do it.
I like the waterfront work.
When you were covering the waterfront, what do you consider to be some of your more important stories that you wrote?
Well, there was a strike in 1946 that was quite important.
There were a wave of strikes.
going on at that time.
Incidentally, I wasn't only on the waterfront.
I also covered the steel strike in the same year, different time of the year.
See, after the war, labor struck back, especially the progressive forces in labor initiated.
Not the top leaders like Bill Green, William Green,
of the miners, a very floppy personality.
There was also one very exciting strike I reported.
It was a waterfront strike of a kind, a shipyard strike in Chester.
The Sun Oil Company owned a big shipyard there.
It was a violent strike.
I saw two men killed in front of my eyes.
One firetruck ran into the picket line, killed him, just ran over him.
That was pretty crude tactics.
But it was a fighting strike.
The shipyard workers, 4,000, had the help of 600 tanker seamen employed also by the Sun Oil Company in tankers not far away.
That was in the winter strike that led to the formation of the National Maritime Union.
So they came and threw their muscles and their fighting spirit into the fight with the shipyard workers.
It was very exciting.
They stopped a line of scabs led by goons, gangsters armed with lead pipes, and won that battle.
Really, the bodies were dropped.
all around the place.
And it's when the other side was losing that it brought in the fire truck.
They brought in cops with tear gas, but that didn't win.
With the National Maritime Union, when in Well, I should say that that
That phase of thethat was the most exciting story, that particular front of the winter seaman strike.
You know, there was a long winter strike that lasted all winter.
I was also in Baltimore during that strike.
There was a wonderful leader down there.
I'll show you his picture.
Patty Whalen, you may have heard of him.
Yes, I have.
A very well-known artist.
She did this.
He afterwards became head of the CIO in Baltimore.
He was a marine engineer and
during the warship was torpedoed.
Did you have any contacts with Paddy Whelan in 1935?
With who?
Did you have any earlier contacts with Paddy Whelan?
Yeah, well I met him earlier, but I didn't know him well until after that we became very good friends.
When he came to New York he came to see me.
Did you have any contacts with the ISU pilot?
Oh.
Any of the editors or the reporters there?
No.
Well, I had some contact.
I was up in the office a couple times, two or three times I remember.
Did you ever do any work for them?
No, no.
Did the Daily Worker ever help them to publish their newspaper?
Well, indirectly, yes, because I think the reporter we had on the waterfront those days did some writing for it.
I'm not positive, but I have that impression.
And they had the active moral support of the people associated with the daily worker, of course.
See, the waterfront...
The leadership of the CM at that time was, much of it was communist.
In your opinion, how long did the communist state have a major influence on the National Maritime Union?
And when did they start to lose their power in the Union?
The decisive thing in Loss of Power was when all known communists, and I would say not only communists, but most active militants, were dropped from the maritime roles by the
Coast Guard, the Coast Guard had charge of that.
Curran, right after he turned, gave a list of names, you see, to the Coast Guard, and they couldn't sell any more.
That was probably started in 49.
Then the government acted too.
We had a very able guy, Ferdinand C. Smith, the Secretary-Treasurer of the Union, a black man, a Jamaican.
He was already deported, and Kern was behind that.
He was a communist, a good speaker, very influential among the seamen.
And it was a persistent drive.
And then, you see, Phil Murray had joined the Cold War himself, actually, in 1947.
And he threw out weight he could against the
the progressive forces, not only communists, progressive forces on the waterfront and in other unions.
You said earlier that Curran turned.
When, in your opinion, did he turn his leadership?
What?
You said earlier that Curran, after Curran had turned.
When, in your opinion, do you think he turned from being a progressive laborer?
The open turning was seen as early as 1946.
Some people who knew him better claimed that they saw signs earlier.
In 1946, Curran broke up the Committee for Maritime Unity.
I don't know if you've heard of that or not.
It was a joint agreement with the International Long Showmen and Warehousemen's Union led by Harry Bridges.
tofor United Action East and West Coast Maritime Unions.
And Kern walked out of it, pulled the National Maritime Union out of it, which was a dirtyreally a treacherous blow.
That was open turning, yes.
But he had been insidiously working against Smith and others earlier.
But it was not done so openly that you could be made an issue.
Perhaps it should have been, I don't know.
Did you ever know Harry Bridges?
Who?
Harry Bridges.
Yes, I know Harry.
Incidentally, I'll show you something.
What were your impressions of Harry Bridges as a labor leader?
Offhand, I'd say the best trade union leader the United States has seen since the days of William Z.
Foster, who led the Great Steel Strike and organized the packinghouse workers.
Did Bridges ever talk to you about Joe Curran?
No, no.
No, I didn't know Harry very intimately.
But I liked him very much and respected him.
We had met, and I covered a number of press conferences with him and so forth.
Did you know Jack Lawrenson?
Yes.
And what were your impressions of him?
Well, I would say just fair.
He didn't impress me greatly, no.
In the National Maritime Union, who do you think was the most dynamic leaders in that union?
Who were?
Well, I'd say Joe Stack was one of them.
Lucky Myers, McKenzie.
McKenzie was another vice president.
What about, how dynamic a leader was Ferdinand Smith?
Well, of course, Ferdinand Smith, yes, yes, yes.
By all means, I...
Do you think that it was a good idea for these members to challenge Curran toward the end of the war in 45 and 46?
Well, they didn'tI don't know thatthe war was over in 46.
In 45, I don't think he was challenged, so I don't know it.
And in 46,
There wasn't an active challenge, as I recall.
What about in Joe Stack's case?
What?
What about in Joe Stack's case?
Well, yeah, that was in 1947, yes, when Kern had Joe Stack expelled, yes.
Very dirty job.
I think I was away at the time.
I forget where now.
Anyhow, I wasn't in on that convention.
Do you think, after the attack at Pearl Harbor, that organized laborers no strike pledge?
Was that a good idea?
No strike pledge?
The principle was a good idea.
I think sometimes it was carried out too inflexibly.
There were some cases where employers took advantage of it and imposed very terrible conditions.
For instance, I'm thinking of...
of coal operators who had bad conditions on the ground, you know, men working in water in very dangerous conditions.
Though the miners in such cases sometimes did have strikes, you see.
Why do you think John L. Lewis changed his position so radically during the war?
Well, that's hard to say.
He had big differences with Louis, I mean with Roosevelt.
You see, Louis, as I said, changed his tactics, but his personality hadn't changed so much.
Louis was a man who wanted power, and he wanted more recognition from Roosevelt than Roosevelt was willing to give him.
He wanted a lot of recognition.
After the war, what was one of the, in your opinion, some of the reasons that brought about this break between Bridges and Curran, particularly with the CMU?
Were there any ideological reasons or incidents?
There was a difference of policy there.
Torn took a very bad position.
What was that?
Against the Committee for Maritime Unity.
He took it for bad reasons, I think.
In other words, he was moving over to a policy of collaboration with the class enemy rather than struggle with it.
After the war was over... What's that?
After the war was over, why did Bridges want to continue the no-strike pledge?
Did you ever talk to him about that?
No, I don't know.
I really don't know.
How can I answer that?
When did you... What?
When did you first become associated with the Communist Party?
Well, I became an open member in 36, but I had worked with the party for a long time before.
I'd been on the paper even though not a member of the party at that time.
It's not a compulsory condition, you see.
And how long did this continue, your relationship with the party?
How long did it continue?
To the present?
Oh, yes.
Ideologically, have you ever had any difficulty at times?
How do you mean?
Have you ever had any problems or disagreements with the party?
Not basic ideological differences.
I disagreed with some things that Barter was trying to do.
For instance?
Well, I disagreed with his idea that you could, that you might say the lamb would lie down together peacefully.
In other words, that the American monopolies would work with labor after the war.
I just couldn't see that.
completely alien to my experience.
Are there any other instances or incidents that you can remember, particularly in your career as a journalist, in respect to the waterfront and the maritime labor movement?
Yes.
Not at hand right now.
I can't remember them, no.
What did you consider to be
your greatest piece of journalism, or the single piece ofpart of your life that you're the most proud of?
It's hard to say.
There were a lot ofI suppose the Spanish War experience would be a tough one, perhaps.
piece of reporting at home.
There would be a couple lynching stories I reported that were very interesting.
And then I spent a month in Texas in 1953 investigating the McCarthyite oil barons.
I got a series of interviews.
I had ten features following each other week by week.
We had a Sunday worker at that time.
I didn't tell them I was with a daily worker.
I just said, I'm a good American.
I want to know what you're doing and tell everyone about it.
Did you ever come up against any...
Any problems, particularly during the McCarthy era?
During what?
During the McCarthy era?
Were you ever harassed by the government?
In Texas or elsewhere?
Anywhere.
Well...
Harassed, yes, but that's something I could carry.
In Texas, I mean...
Earl Brown was in prison on a passport case at Roosevelt after his community sentence.
While he was in prison, I was sent to Wichita, his hometown, to get stories about his boyhood there and his youth.
I got a series of eight articles.
I talked to a lot of people who had known him.
The last one I talked to was his baseball captain.
